titleInfo.title: Forecasting Prescribed Fires Using Weather Forecasts, Satellite Data, and Machine Learning

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Prescribed fires and wildfires are widespread sources of air pollutants. Prescribed fires, which are used for agriculture, fire hazard reduction, and land clearing, last only several hours and their locations change from one day to the next. Current air quality forecast models do not account for this daily variability in emissions. This work develops a new method for statistically forecasting the locations of prescribed fires several days in advance, which can be integrated into dynamical air quality models. Our prescribed fire forecast employs a machine learning algorithm with gradient-boosted decision trees (XGBoost). The forecast model is trained on a new dataset of prescribed fires in the southeastern United States, which excludes known wildfires from satellite fire detections. The model is separately trained for each calendar month using predictors that include meteorology, land use, and land cover. Bootstrapping is used to assess model uncertainty. The model is tested on independent data, from which we evaluate forecast performance and skill relative to traditional forecasting techniques like persistence. Our model produces dramatically better forecasts of prescribed fires in the southeastern US than current methods, particularly during spring when most prescribed fires occur. During peak prescribed fire activity in March, our fire forecasts have 45% greater prediction skill (Brier skill score) than one-day persistence forecasting and 60-62% greater skill than two-day and three-day persistence. Over the entire year, XGBoost outperforms climatology in eight out of twelve months and outperforms one-day persistence forecasting in eleven out of twelve months. Compared to two-day and three-day persistence forecasts, XGBoost outperforms in all months. These results are statistically significant at a 95% confidence level. We use multiple methods (partial dependence and feature importance) to identify the major predictor variables that influence the forecast and we find results consistent with weather conditions that prescribed burners are known to consider (e.g. relative humidity, wind speed). Lastly, we also consider the potential climate impacts on prescribed fires, using data from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 6 (CMIP 6) for our analysis. Output from XGBoost suggests considerable regional and seasonal variability in the future prescribed fire landscape, although there is some model agreement in terms of which seasons could see increases/decreases in prescribed burning. Integrating this prescribed fire emissions forecast into dynamical air quality models has the potential to improve air pollution forecast guidance for the public and decisionmakers.
